reviewText:
I used to scour Steam for local co-op games that could provide a great party experience. This game takes the cake. Hidden in Plain Sight is the single best and most fun local co-op game I've ever played out of over 50 that I've bought and tried.

I've had a room full of people cursing at each other, laughing their asses off to tears, and jumping up and down, while at other times the whole room is silent in concentration and suspense, every set of eyes dead-focused on trying not to be caught by the others' - all caused by this wonderfully simple yet strategically genius video game.

GET IT!
voteText: 25 of 27 people (93%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I may only have a small amount of time racked up on here, but rest assured I've sunk many hours into Hidden in Plain Sight on the Xbox 360 version, and man am I glad to see it here on Steam too. Hidden in Plain Sight is a collection of five minigames, all of which are best played with four players, right there at in the same room as you. They all insanely fun (Ninja Party is my favourite) and rely on you keeping your cool as others try to reveal and capture you, while at the same time, you're trying to capture everyone else.

Ninja Party, for example, has 2-4 players all as identical ninjas, amongst 30 other identical ninjas. Each player must either be the last one standing by eliminating the other players, or by touching 5 statues scattered around the room, which play a sound each time they're touched. Do you run straight for all the statues, aiming for a quick win but putting yourself in danger of being noticed? Or do you wait for an unsuspecting player to set off the statue, and slay them from behind?

This is one of the most fun, if not THE most fun local multiplayer games I've ever played, hands down. This is what multiplayer gaming was about: having fun with REAL PEOPLE, before it all became about leaderboards and strangers from halfway across the world. People that you know; friends, family, whoever. Anyone can play this game, from your pro MLG 360 noscopers to your filthy pleb casuals.

And it's so refreshing to see local multiplayer games make a comeback, even if most of them are indie titles. Hidden in Plain Sight is a prime example of a simple and brilliant idea with simple and brilliant excecution. It doesn't fall prey to other indie game tropes such an annoyingly pretentious storyline or an obsession with unique" and overused gimmicks.

Yeah

reviewText: A fantastic 5 dollar game that requires you to actually have friends (I know right?) at your computer. The variety is great, and it's a great package. Pros: Super fun, cool graphics, great soundtrack\nCons: None, except one annoying thing: IF YOU ARE GOING TO PORT A GAME FROM XBOX YOU SHOULDN'T HAVE TO HAVE 2-4 XBOX REMOTES PLUGGED IN AT ALL TIMES! What the heck dude! Heads up, it's a PC, not an XBox. Please add support for one person on keyboard/2 people on keyboard + XBox remote support. Even games like Gang Beasts let you play 2 people on the same keyboard. This is not more complex then Gang Beasts.

reviewText: I've played this game on Ouya and then the PC version, and everytime it was increadibly easy to get people into playing it and it was a massive amount of fun as well.\n\nAlso, Steam version improves on earlier existing PC version. This has the same customization options as on other platforms now, which I feel is a must-have addition, since I sometimes feel the need to tweak the settings the way we want to play (for example, I occasionally feel that 3 sniper shots is way too much for Catch a Thief, or I want bots to run as well in Death Race). So even if you, like me, have the previously released PC version, I would definitely recommend picking it up.

reviewText:
Played this game with four friends with controllers last night. The concept behind this game is certainly cool, but core gameplay needs more work. While there are many game modes, the game boils down to some portion of friends are trying to blend in with the computer controlled characters, and the other friends are trying to pick the humans out. Usually picking them out is controlling a cross-hair and having only 3 bullets to do so. The main problem is that picking out the humans is almost random - for most modes there is no easy mechanism to tell who your friends are. When we put this to the test with four friends last night, we got bored because of the randomness - it is surprisingly easy to act like a computer-driven character.

Pros:
+There are different modes of gameplay that are fairly distinct
+Controller support is good, and there are great ways to 'swap' roles each round
+Its cheap

Cons:
-The game modes and core design need to be worked out more, some way to make it more competitive
-Graphics look stock from some game-building program - there is no unifying theme (i.e. skeletons, ninjas, snowmen, and then hand-drawn images etc.)
-Local co-op only, although this would not be fun online

When it comes to local co-op, I'd steer away from this one.

Take on five different game modes in which you need to blend amongst the AI crowd to fulfil your goal.

-Punch out others blending amongst the crowd in 'Ninja' mode
-Snipe thieves in a crowded room
-Keep your cool and suss out your friends as you crawl your way to the finish line past snipers in 'Race' mode
-Defend the royal family and take out ninjas in 'Knights vs. Ninjas'
-Seek and snipe assassins in the aptly named 'Assassin' mode

Just had a bunch of people over for a couch-gaming session, and this was the hit of the evening!

The varied game modes really let you keep things fresh, and they're really different strategically from each other.

The only issue we had was that it took us a while to figure out that in thief mode and assasin mode, the coins don't disappear and people don't appear dead until the sniper scopes actually view the coin/victim.

One other thing we wished for was a 3v1-type team-swapper, so that we could always have 3 snipers and one thief, but have who is the thief change each round.

Really fun local-multiplayer-only game.  A good choice when you've got a mix of players. Regular, casual, and non-gamers will all enjoy this equally.  There are also variants, all well-designed, that you can switch to to keep things interesting.

If you want to play this game YOU NEED A CONTROLLER, I ADVISE MORE THAN TWO.\n\nThe game is a really fun party type of game. It's rare to have a local co-op game nowadays,especially one this fun. Get some controllers and some friends and sit down and play the five or so different modes. Tweak the settings for even more fun.
